all_paragraphs: Chances are if you’re reading this article, you have a decent grasp of English. If you’re from India, it’s also likely that English is not the only language you know. Most Indians are multilingual 💬 and study more than one language in school.
However, can you guess the percentage of English speakers in the country? The answer may surprise you. Give it a go!🏃
The percentage of English speakers in India is…just 10% [1]. That’s 10% of a one billion-plus population!
Most Indians have Hindi as their first language, followed by Marathi, Telugu, Punjabi, etc. For a lot of people living in rural communities, English is not even a language they understand or speak.
As a side note, for an insight into the demographic profile of English speakers in India, refer [2].
Natural Language Processing, usually shortened as NLP, is an interdisciplinary field that deals with the interaction between computers and humans using the natural language.
NLP is a way for computers to analyze, understand and derive meaning from human language in a smart and useful way.
Now that the background of languages in India and purpose of NLP is clear, let’s dig deeper into why this is important.
The dream of an all-inclusive Digital India cannot be realized without bringing NLP research and application in India at par with that of languages like English.
When engaging with smartphones, the language barrier can be a huge obstacle to many.

Take the case of farmers and agriculture which has long been considered the backbone of India. Farmers play an obviously important role in feeding the country. Helping such farmers improve their methods (through precision agriculture, farmer helplines, chatbots, etc) has been an aim of development projects and an important part of the fight against global hunger. But many small farmers are not knowledgeable in English, meaning it is difficult for them to share and learn about new farming practices since most of the information is in English.

Can you imagine a mobile application like Google assistant but tailor-made for Indian farmers? It’d allow them to ask their questions in their native tongue, the system would understand their query and suggest relevant information from around the globe 🌏.
Do you think this is possible to do without NLP for Indian regional languages?
And, this is just one possible use-case. From making information more accessible to understanding farmer suicides [4], NLP has a huge role to play.

Thus, there is a clear need to bolster NLP research for Indian languages so that such people who don’t know English can get “online” in the true sense of the word, ask questions, in their mother tongue and get answers.
In fact, people at AI4Bharat, a platform to accelerate AI innovation in India, summarized the scenario quite aptly:
Though India is rich in languages, it is poor in resources on these languages.
The need also becomes clear when we look at some of the applications of NLP in India.
There are many more. The ideal scenario would be to have corpora and tools available in as good quality as they are for English to support work in these areas.

By the way, AI (natural language processing) is increasingly being used for creative tasks like storytelling. There are already AI story generators which generate convincing storylines in English. Imagine a day when Indian kids can play with such AI generators to create stories in Indian vernacular languages! Nowadays we can also use AI to add voiceovers from text to our videos.

But there are some issues which arise due to differences between English and Indian languages. Thus, they are specific to Indian languages.
1. In sentence structuring, English uses subject-verb-object word order whereas Hindi uses subject-object-verb.
2. Presence of post-position case markers instead of prepositions.
3. Words can be moved freely in many Indian languages without changing the meaning.
1. Scarcity of annotated corpora and tools.
2. Lack of education and training institutes.
3. Large set of morphological variants.
Online resources to learn NLP for Indian languages are limited as compared to English.
1. Large number of morphological variants and word root complexity.
2. Punjab has different dialects in different regions of Punjab with minor variations. This increases preprocessing work.
3. Hard to look for datasets related to a specific region.
A lot of datasets available at authentic sources like Kaggle, UCI machine learning repository, etc are in English.
Limited datasets, corpora and other resources are a huge hurdle. There is only one list of stopwords having 184 words in total, released for the public back in 2016. Refer [5] for more details.
It’s interesting to note that when I searched for resources for telugu NLP, the top GitHub result I found was this and it’s 4 years old at the time of writing with no updates.

Telugu does have a dataset on Kaggle, however. There is also a dataset for Tamil. Nonetheless, the discussion and kernels are very few and seemingly haven’t drawn much attention from Indian data science community.

The journey of NLP in India seems long and daunting but as the famous proverb goes:
journeys of a thousand miles begin with a single step!

Good news is that due to the efforts of hundreds of researchers, industry specialists and students, we have made significant progress in a very short time. Future of NLP in India seems bright and applications limitless.
But again as Robert Frost famously wrote in his poem, ‘Stopping by Woods on a Snowy Evening’, we have miles to go before we sleep.
